Expectation1: Teach children about Jewish traditions, values, and history
Situation1: The child's bar mitzvah is approaching, and they have not yet mastered the Torah portion.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Polls stay open all day and the voter has a light schedule.
Story:
I woke up early, heart pounding with the weight of the day ahead. My son’s bar mitzvah was just a week away, and he still stumbled over the Hebrew in his Torah portion. As a Jewish parent, I felt the pressure to guide him, to make sure he understood not just the words, but the meaning behind them. My own parents had always stressed the importance of tradition, of passing down our history, and I wanted to do the same for him.

But today was also Election Day. I had promised myself I would vote—my civic duty, my voice in the future of our country. The polling station was open all day, and my schedule was light, but every time I sat down with my son, I saw the minutes ticking by. If I left now, I’d lose precious time helping him practice. If I stayed, I risked forgetting or running out of time to vote. The expectations pressed in from both sides: to be a good parent, a good Jew, and a responsible citizen. I felt torn, anxiety rising as I tried to decide which role to honor first.
